Gateway To Gaming Presents:

Ladykiller in a Bind, A Visual Novel Review

Disclosure: This visual novel was bought by the review.

Visual Novel experience: Muv-Luv Alternative, Kindred Spirits on the Roof, Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc, VA-11 Hall-A: Cyberpunk Bartender Action

Please note: I will try to keep this as spoiler free as possible. If you are interested in spoilers, I don't mind explaining in detail with a link to a separate group.

The visual aesthetic's quality is a mixed bag, but nothing dips beneath terrible. The backgrounds and environmental set pieces are absolutely beautiful to look at, ranging from the hallways of the cruise ship to the dinning facility and pool tables located in the lounge. Random pieces of art are also included via the third epilogue, which had a couple of noteworthy pieces done in black and white shading. The UI and the option menu are all presented cleanly and in uniform fashion, something I wish a lot of other visual novels could mimic. In terms of the sexual content in this game, it is very tame with simply drawn genitalia (nothing detailed) and the most extreme act being penetration. It is nothing to write home about and due to some serious story issues, feels more tacked on than genuine. Yes, BDSM is also featured, but the use of the crop is never shown, just emphasized by sound effects. 

Character avatars are shown during conversation to help specify who is talking, but they are all rather similar in terms of build and height. The main menu screen illustrates this best, having each character side by side with their outfits and hair being the only real feature separating them. Faces, unfortunately, also suffer the exact same issue most visuals novels have when dealing with their characters. The faces are interchangeable with no definition to the way noses look and provide the strange case of "same face, different hair style and eye color. It just feels lazy, a feature that can easily be fixed by giving the time to provide cheek definition. This makes the characters look sterile, clean cut and bland. Thankfully, much more care was given to the outfits that range from spectacular (looking at your wardrobe Boss) to simply quaint. Clothing wrinkles and stretch lines were sown into most poses as well. The game actually uses multiple poses, different angles for each character that helps convey emotion over simply having the assumption from a single avatar. If it wasn't for the faces though, I probably would have given the character artwork a plus.

Music, I am pleased to announce, was mellow throughout and never seemed to outstay its' welcome during the short duration of conversations. During times of tension, the tempo picks up and helps carry some scenes that otherwise fall flat from delivered dialog. It is by no means terrible, but once I finished the game for the third time, I honestly couldn't remember any of the melodies used. It would also help if the main menu could feature at least some form of music. Sound effects are minor, mostly given to the pounding of waves against the hull and the swift cracks of the crop. The only major omission from this visual novel is voice acting, which again, leaves the music to help carry scenes. Granted, the developer's other games lacked voice talent, but they were also not $30 dollars. 

Conversations play a major role in the manipulation game, influencing the way the story progress in regards to the individual classmates. While the main story follows the same script, the player can choose to interact with specific people at special times of the day, adding the chance to garner more votes while trying to avoid triggering suspicion. Each character has dialog paths that can unlock sentences worth of different text and others that are needed to progress down the path to either a peaceful resolution, breaking it off in poor taste or commemorating friendship on silk sheets. Certain conversation options are also blocked that can only be unlocked if certain interactions occur to gain information regarding that character. Options can also open up or disappear depending on how long you continue to listen to a conversation, which can be beneficial or harmful. Honestly, if the player goes to far into a conversation, they can roll back up using the mouse wheel and select a less impactful option in most cases. How can someone tell? Every dialog option has their profits and losses written next too it, which makes deciding on a specific path incredible easy. It also removes any real danger of rousing suspicion (except for one unavoidable situation) and makes the conversations less enjoyable. It is a great system (in terms of removing options) dragged down by unnecessary hand holding and a lack of discoverability. 

The game also handles the idea of a fail-state poorly. If a player somehow manages to get five suspicion points, the game cuts to the same conversation, the same outcome, then uses the unreliable narrator to reload the same time of day for a retry. This was a missed opportunity to examine the reactions that would have been made, leading to more potential endings and uses of the manipulation narrative. It all feels too "safe" in a genre that has given some very amazing story arcs during what equates to a game over. It boils down to a missed opportunity in a disappointing story.

Story-wise, this is a mess of a title. This is without taking into account the dialog, the character motivations, the general lack of chemistry and the themes used by the developer (which are all subjective). It takes at least three play-throughs to get all the information needed to understand the main plot and goes from out of left field to incredibly outlandish for what was advertised as a simple story about high school romance and votes. The cruise is simply an excuse to set up the protagonist for the ending and doesn't involve any of the classmates plot wise, which makes the cruise seem more like filler except for the interaction with The Stalker and The Beauty (who wipes away your suspicion points if you decide to submit to her). It is hard to really pin point the issue without spoilers, so I will try it this way: this is two visual novels wrapped into one, with the first being a "fish out of water" romance comedy and the second being an origin story to a Call of Duty villain. That is how disjointed and out of place the ending feels, which would have probably just been a good place to start the planned sequel for this game. 

The core premise also takes a nose dive off the plot-line close to the end as it is revealed the need for votes is arbitrary, resulting in the same ending regardless of how many are acquired. On a side note: votes are needed to unlock certain paths during Day 6 for individual characters, not the main plot. It doesn't help that the chemistry introduced is paper thin (for the actual brother, not the sister). The reason for adding the consequences for certain dialog options was made to help play off the brother, I understand this, but there is barely any relationship or motivations revealed outside "he is my rival" or "I use to date her." If there were more details involving situations like the unavoidable conundrum I mentioned early, it might have been needed. The characters just don't have a well written history to give off or promoted angles to make them anything but one dimensional. 

Technical issues are also present on this little lust boat. Crashes have occurred three times during my play-throughs, once for hitting New Game and twice while loading two separate saves. Dialog also has a tendency to repeat itself, as if the scene was meant to be a placeholder for the finished sentence. Music would something play while I was reading something, cut off while I was reading that same page, then start again before clicking to the next page.

I'll open by admitting the visual novel isn't one of my preferred game formats. I've tried quite a few over the years, but for the most part I lose interest within the first twenty minutes or so. This isn't because of the lack of interactivity or action; it's because, just in general, for games theoretically focused on their textual content, the writing is abysmal.

Ladykiller in a Bind had me hooked before the introductory segment had even ended.

Now I'm not going to tell you the game is entirely lacking in cheesiness - that is, in fact, part of the appeal! What I will say is that its writing is clever, humorous, and, perhaps most importantly, sincere. Scenes that would make me cringe to read in other contexts WORK in this game: they're set up properly, they feel like they're given appropriate weight and respect, and those "uncensored" moments aren't just played for titillation. The plot is, on its face, ridiculous, basically playing a social media popularity contest in an unrealistic setting, and yet through that vehicle it manages to create a variety of interesting, believable, and widely varied characters.

As for the structure and mechanics of the game, the way it approaches your standard conversation branching activity is a bit different from the usual formats of either quicktime style "pick your response before the conversation moves on without you" or "everything hinges on this one choice" that seems most prevalent in these kinds of games. Instead, you get a sort of gradient of choice over the course of a conversation, with options popping up and gradually fading away as they're relevant to the conversation at hand. It lends a sense of realism to the flow of conversation: do you butt in right away as soon as you think of something to say? Do you decide to wait until you can come up with something a little more witty or biting? Are you going to miss your moment entirely trying to think of that perfect response that never comes?

This is a big part of what kept me engaged with the game as I went through it when I might have otherwise lost interest in a core plot that isn't my usual fare, that sense of needing to really be in the conversation and gauge my role in it to decide how and when I need to make a move, if I want to speak up at all, to achieve my goals. It's more complicated than simply "who do I want to make happy?" and then picking whatever seems like it will go that direction as soon as I can. Well, at least it was for me, as I got to know the characters. If you really just want to make your goal "impress X," you can do that, too; it doesn't try to trick you with secretly sabotaging conversation choices. However, as in a real conversation, timing and context is important: what you think might be the best way to get what you want could bite you in the ass if you misjudge your audience.

Highly recommended for anyone with even a passing interest in VNs, and even for people who, like me, usually don't find the genre interesting at all. You might be pleasantly surprised.

Ladykiller in a Bind is my GOTY for 2016.

I've written a lot about My Twin Brother Made Me Crossdress As Him And Now I Have To Deal With A Geeky Stalker And A Domme Beauty Who Want Me In A Bind!! in my continuing efforts to convince people to buy it, but here's a bit of a short form review for you if you just want a simple opinion to determine whether or not to buy it:
Ladykiller in a bind continues Christine Love's excellent and deeply thoughtful approach to games, and is both incredibly funny and very interesting. If you're balking at the price for a visual novel, absolutely don't, it's worth every penny. It has a cast of memorable characters who are in some ways very much fufilling and archetype, but are not two dimension enough to be summed up by that archetype. The dynamics between characters are good, the dialogue is top notch, and the use of choices and branching paths is stellar. If you at all are into the idea of visual novels, or even just reading a comedy with pictures, seriously just buy this game.

If you want to hear a longer form review, here's a longer bit of writing about it:

Ladykiller in a Bind, or Incredibly Long Title No One But Me Actually Uses, is a game about... well, I mean, the title explains a lot of it. The main character is forced to act as her twin brother for a week on a graduation cruise, and encounters a not really a stalker geek and an absolutely a domme beauty, and sometimes gets tied up. In impersonating her brother, the main character can get "suspicion" and if you rack up five suspicion, it's game over. Meanwhile, you also collect votes to win a mysterious game with five million dollars on the line. Also, you have sex with your brother's friends and enemies, probably. There's a lot of sex in Ladykiller, I'm just putting that out there right now. You can have sex with the majority of the cast, and every one of the seven nights ends with the main character in either The Beauty or The Hacker's bed. Speaking of The Beauty and The Hacker, character names in Ladykiller are set by the player. Whenever you met a new character for the first time or another character mentions them before you meet them, a quick info screen shows up and prompts you to pick a name from either one of two suggested choices or a custom name.

Christine Love is one of the very few developers of visual novels interested in poking at what the medium can do. Hate Plus was particularly interesting in a lot of ways regarding the fourth wall, and Ladykiller is a game that subverts a lot of how visual novels work normally in a thoughtful way. I've heard it described as "a power fantasy for socially awkward people" and in a way that's right. In most visual novel type games, you have to pick the right option to get what you want, and then if you pick wrong something bad happens. Mostly you just sit there advancing text until a choice happens. In Ladykiller, there's two main differences. First, options pop up during dialogue without interrupting it, and you choose when to speak up. Sometimes you'll reach a point where you have to say something if you've been quiet for too long, but you can cut off characters all the time or jump in eagerly to agree. Secondly, you generally know the outcome of what you're going to say- if it's going to generate suspicion, or get you votes you'll know. If you're about to lose the chance to say an option, it indicates it, and if something opens up more choices, ends a scene or closes off a character, it'll tell you.

What this means is the game becomes less about figuring out the "right" thing to say, and more about figuring out what you want to result from it. On Twitter in the runup to the release, Christine mentioned that she wanted to make "good easy choices" - "that is to say I’m interested in making it easy for the player to do things they wouldn’t normally do, to do the interesting-but-wrong thing". You can generally be an asshole and absolutely know you can get away with it. The game even gives you an excuse- you're trying to act like your brother, and he's an asshole, go for it! On the other hand, suspicion is pretty easy to reset, so if you don't want to be bound to acting like your asshole brother, you can be more noble than he would be without necessarily getting game over. It makes for a more interesting dynamic than "which is the right answer" or "which of these answers is the one to get the route you want". The design of the game in general is really nice as well; there's stylish cards for picking where to go during the day, the menus and options are all nice, and there's well done dynamic music. Characters change outfit every day, and will sometimes be wearing something different if you run into them in the bar compared to the library, so it's significantly more dynamic than the standard "ten sprites for the entire game and maybe two outfits" deal.

So, let's talk about humour: Ladykiller in a Bind is fucking hilarious. I don't think there's a single other game where I've laughed out loud as often as in Ladykiller. If I posted every screenshot I've taken of lines that made me laugh it'd be a wall. The game is just really funny. That said, Ladykiller is also an incredibly honest game in a lot of ways, and part of that is that it's honest to Christine Love's sense of humour, so if tumblr jokes or general memes piss you off probably you'll get annoyed sometimes. That's not all of the humour, by any means, but there's plenty of it, with The Hacker especially. I think the humour as a whole easily stands up even if you don't know any of the memes or tumblrisms referenced, however.

Now would be a good time to mention there's a joke SFW option that puts christmas sweaters on everyone in sex scenes! And that brings us to the sex scenes. I mentioned before that Ladykiller is honest, and while sometimes obviously things are character opinions, sometimes things are said that I'm fairly confident are things that Christine Love thinks. And a lot of these are about relationships. The sex scenes are full of explicit consent, jokes, honest conversation, and exploring relationships. Almost all of the characterisation of The Hacker and The Beauty is done in the sex scenes, inverting the normal "get to know this character and then bang them" paradigm. The game doesn't shy away from sex, but it also doesn't treat sex as some kind of ultimate achievement. It's a part of a relationship.

Anyway, I could basically talk about this game forever, but there's a limit to how much anyone wants to read. It's seriously well worth your time and money.

Ladykiller in a Bind is a game about control.  It is also a visual novel with interesting choice systems.  You play as "the Beast" (every character can be renamed), twin sister of scheming weirdo "the Prince".  Your brother has kidnapped you and made you take his place on a cruise ship full of his classmates, who are mostly also scheming weirdoes.  Also, he has arranged a Game to take place on this ship, where everyone is given a vote and the ability to trade it, and whoever has the most votes at the end of the cruise supposedly wins a bunch of money.

Ladykiller revolves around two systems: votes and suspicion.  If you're concerned with The Game, you can work to earn votes from people by (for example) doing what they want or tricking them.  However, many actions also arouse suspicion.  You're pretending to be your brother and do not understand any of his relationships with the other people on the ship, so there is a bit of danger in almost any conversation.  Suspicion is always bad, and if you get five points of it, the game ends.  However, it might be worth taking the suspicion hit in order to change someone's opinion of you from whatever impression your brother had left.

The game is abundantly clear about exactly what effect any option will have.  You never have to guess at the overall outcome of a choice.  When you pick where to go at various times of day, you can see the potential range for vote and suspicion gain for that scene, and when picking options within conversations, you can also see how many votes/suspicion you would gain as well as whether the option might open up more options down the line or just end the scene outright.

The conversation options themselves are mostly interjections.  They appear in the middle of a conversation and allow you to interrupt with something.  If you continue the conversation, they fade and eventually disappear as the moment passes.  However, occasionally there is a consequence for not interjecting, and in those cases the options will not fade until you have made a choice.

To further complicate the votes/suspicion system, at the end of each day you choose to spend time with either the Beauty or the Stalker.  The Beauty will erase all of your suspicion, allowing you to act like a complete fool during the day, and the Stalker will give you votes, making it easier to win The Game, but requiring that you take more care with the rest of your actions.

I primarily wanted to talk about the mechanics of the game in this review, but of course I should also mention that the game has numerous sex scenes, mostly at night.  A lot of the most interesting conversation choices are in those scenes, and you can really alter the tone of your relationship with the Beauty or the Stalker depending on what kind of options you pick.  Like the rest of the game, these scenes are about control, and either the giving or taking of it.

The story is rather silly and I suggest that you not spend too much time thinking about things like how anyone could actually mistake the Beast for the Prince, even if they do have roughly the same face and hair, or how a single school could end up with so many horny Machiavellian backstabbers.  Just take it for what it is and accept that this insanity is happening and that you need to find a way out of it with some shred of dignity hopefully intact (or not!).

Also, the game has a fantastic dynamic soundtrack whose songs change along with what is happening in the conversation.
